segments.text: It's real hard to just strike out and say, we're going to do this.
And it's hard to explain, I think, to the average citizen how engineering research affects their lives until you can give them some concrete examples.
And so what we've tried to do is put it in language and explain it, especially to the legislature, what it is we do and how it has an impact on the future.
Isn't Invent kind of targeted to the individuals?
Exactly.
Doesn't matter where, you know, anybody, anywhere, you have an idea and you send it in and it will be reviewed
The success ratio in selection is very small because most things have been thought of before or have been done better already.
But it gives you an opportunity to find out for no charge if there's a potential for something that will... We're primarily targeted at things that will create more jobs in the state.
Either enhance the
productivity or the product line of businesses already in existence and or create new businesses that will hire people.
How does the Research Foundation and TEAS work together?
The Research Foundation is an entity that
all of our federal companies right now.
To give you an example of what they, how they function, we cannot, we can buy a boat or a vessel for environmental engineering to use to do their research with, but we can't purchase the insurance.
State entities can't buy insurance.
They just, well, if you try to insure all these buildings, you give them a bill for a building a year for their premiums.
And so it's a good fiscal policy, except under certain circumstances.
And so there is a need to have a vehicle that can do those kinds of things for you.
So they serve special purpose needs.
And in the past, they have also
than an awful lot of the proposal preparation and the budget advisement and contract negotiations for various major contracts with especially the federal government.
And at one point, they were almost one and the same thing for a while in the 60s.
There wasn't much separation.
They've been fairly well separated since the late 70s, haven't they?
As far as I know, they were very distinct operations when I came to work.

and have probably grown more distinct as opposed to a lot of the services we are able to do sometimes easier or quicker or better or what we find we have to justify to the researcher that we're purchasing a service we want to send your contract through the research foundation and we've got to make sure that the researcher gets his
that we're being cost-effective.
During your short stint here, what has been the biggest period of change in TEAS?
Oh, I think the fact that Skip was director has changed the whole perspective of the agency.
And that it was much more aggressively tuned to serving the state and meeting the nation's problems.
We found that so many people... T's had been a passive organization.
Responsive, but passive, I think, in the past.

And we found that many people who didn't know that it existed and that it could provide statewide service might have been on the way to creating another entity that was a state agency to do exactly what we were chartered to do initially.
And so, with that threat or possibility in her, we realized that we really did exist and we did have a state charter.
We were not just here to serve Texas A&M University.
We were a college station.
We were here to serve the state of Texas.
And we can do that here.
This is a good place to do it.
We're structured well to do that.
We just needed to be more open with state and public officials in saying that we recognize our state charter and we're interested in working on state problems.
Do you think there was national emphasis before?
has always been in securing contracts.
We've always worked on a national basis as far as liaison with meeting Air Force and DOD and those kinds of
But I think that Texas is in the limelight now.
We are what's going to happen to the nation in many respects.
The problems that you address here are also the problems of the nation.
And so it's just become very focused.
And so by doing more, most often we do it.
Were there any particular critical turning points besides, was there a time that you felt TEAS was threatened because of these new organizations?
Well?
I don't know if there was any particular piece of legislation threatened.
It didn't get quite as far as legislation, but
The governor's commission, Governor Plymouth set up the Texas 2000 and early on,
I'd have to stop to get documents for you, but we'll do that later.
Porter went over to participate in the engineering extension service staff development conference.
And one of the speakers was Vic Arnold, and he was quoted from part of the research that he had done as director of the Texas 2000.
It stated that there is no state agency to do R&D in the state of Texas.
And we're sitting over here doing, we started TTI and we're doing about $24 million worth of research per year.
And so we thought maybe we might need to go talk to this person and let him know that we exist.
And so we did that.
And actually it's one of the recommendations initially.
They were going to recommend that there be a state agency created to do
research and development technology.
We were invited to make a presentation to the subcommittee on research and development for the Texas 2000.
This was Paul Thayer while he was still president of LTV before he became president of the National Chamber of Commerce.
He went to some government position too.
A.B.
Holliday, she's the largest realtor in the world.
That's like 27 offices in the Dallas area.
Just a wide variety of people.
I think Dean Rostow from the LBJ School in UT Austin.
Harvey McManus from the Institute of Constructive Capitalism.
but a wide variety of people on this panel.

And we went and told them what the Engineering Experiment Station did and described to them the concept of Invent, which was just then coming up as a way to address the needs of the Joe Blow on the street in dealing with the ideas, how to spur entrepreneurism, and how to get every person
to see that there is a need for R&D in their activities and that they can have a good idea and somebody can help them with that.
The final recommendation and the target that you guys were looking for was that there be the Institute for Ventures and New Technology, which changed names about six times in that process.
We had to call them all the time to tell them what we were calling it that week.
It serves as a prototype.
for similar types of efforts.
And there wasn't a recommendation to create a new state agency to do R&D.
That's probably the closest that I... Was there recognition by them that A&M existed for R&D?
Oh, well, with the invent statement, yeah.
That was a major coup, I think, because these were...
people in Austin that had worked for UT before and went to work on this project and went back to work for UT as Director of Bureau of Business Research afterwards.
So it opened their eyes a lot.
Is that the most successful period?
Well, I think we're getting in vent past.
I really don't think that people internally
had as much confidence as people externally had that legislation would pass in a very hectic session and that funding would be secure.
We got a million dollars in a very, very tight time.
fiscal biennium.

And the Legislative Budget Board didn't recommend any money for it because they felt like the legislature needed to say this was something so new and so different that they had to have the whole House and Senate vote on it to demonstrate that this was the expenditure of money for the public good.
Because it was, it created a precedent that had not existed before.
There is state law that says you cannot spend money, you can't give money to a private individual.
We couldn't invest in private, for private money.
We had to invest for the public good.
And we had to then do, our legislation, what it really says is that we agree that the Institute for Business and Technology exists for the public good of the state.
And even though it helps individual people, that's going to benefit the whole state in the long run.
By creating more jobs?
Exactly.
And so that bill did not pass until May 26th.
The session was over very shortly thereafter.
And at the last minute,
was added, the money was added as a rider in the appropriations bill.
To pay, to give us money to operate that on.
That was a major turning point, I think.
I'm trying to think if there have been others, because it seems like there have.
Here, it's just one turning point after another.
I think that another turning point is our working relationships and our
our cooperative agreements, move to the distributed industrial research centers, if that's what we're going to call it.
So that that will be a milestone with you.
Is there a project that you think T should have pursued that they didn't?
Oh, there's a lot of those.
We're still
working to find ways to work with Mexico and Canada to establish international ties and linkages.
And that just doesn't happen overnight.
It's going to take a long time.
When did that process begin?
Oh, again, I think that was a mindset that we all felt comfortable with when we came in.
It hadn't started before that time?
Well, there had been...
I think Vincent will tell you there have been .
It's just something that we're just now beginning to see the real importance of recognizing we're in a global economy and participating on an international basis.
The effort you're making right now is within the continent, right?
Yeah.
You had made a comment about the role of TEAS in education and the engineers.
Can you expand any more on what you think that role is and how it has changed if it has changed?
Well, we're evolving another, I don't know if it will ever become a division, but it's a laboratory center called the Learning Technology Center.
And this is a way to link engineers and educators.
to work on the question of how people learn.
And I think technology is a tool that I don't know that current theory on learning is transferable to technological tools.
I think you may learn very differently.
using a terminal, using a video disk, using, you may not have to be in a particular building, you may not have to be in a particular place.
Those flexibilities can change the educational environment and can change the whole educational process.
Many people in public schools are adamantly opposed to that.
because they aren't convinced that we'll do anything different.
And much of what's been produced so far is not very good.
We're just on the verge of having anybody put together anything that doesn't want to just entertain you.
It's as close to basic research as I have found that can be done.
What about the role of the research and the aerodynamic research used in teaching aerodynamics here?
Is there much interplay between those?
Well, I think that...
Let me see if I understand your question.
Are you interested in how technology impacts teaching, aerodynamics?
How research is going on at TEAS?
Is it used in classroom instruction?
You will find that 80% of our employees are faculty in Texas A&E.
They're joint employees.
We just buy out their time.
It's really what it boils down to.
The things they learn in the laboratory are immediately transferable to their classroom.
And in fact, in a lot of cases, much of the work done in the laboratory is done by the graduate students.
So it's a learning, what I hope evolves with our research part.
And what I hope, what I think is going to happen to education.
at the graduate level eventually, especially in the technical areas.
It's like we have teaching hospitals for medicine and veterinary medicine right now.

We have teaching companies that come and locate in research parks where not only do you have the laboratories where you're really doing the work and doing whatever it is the company does, but those become a learning mechanism.
The buildings may have classrooms built right into them.
And the people who are in industry also become instructors, teachers, or facilitators in that process.
Which is, it's a way down the road, I think, but it's kind of awesome.
The research part that you're talking about, how is that, what is the status of that at this point?
As far as I know,
They have selected the A&E firm, architecture and engineering firm, that's going to do the construction of the streets, sewers.
They've got to get all the utilities set up.
You wouldn't...
But they do have funding to construct it.
They're going to do that.
I think they've appropriated probably about $7 million.
Is it state funding?
Well, it's available fund money.
What they're going to do is...
you know, you wouldn't go buy a lot in a subdivision if it didn't have a road, if it didn't have a sewer, if it didn't have water and utilities, and you didn't know how much it cost.
So they're in the process of getting that.
But they have committed themselves, TEAS has committed themselves to doing this?
Now it's the university that's actually the person.
It's not going to be a TEAS?
No, we're connected to it in that we're supportive of it, but it's actually, there's a vice chancellor for
the Research Park and Corporate Relations, named Mark Mooney, and he reports to the Chancellor.
So it's really a system project.
Which he's only been part of.
Yeah.
How have external events affected your research, state or national?
The economy?
Oh, I think that we're
I think external events affect us in that there are things that need to be done in research areas that sometimes are easier to quote unquote sell based upon what happens in the outside world.

people become much more receptive to education technology since nation at risk came out since the national reports have come out since we've had the governor's report on education okay that is a topic that will be hopefully the legislature will be receptive to when you go back next time but they're receptive to their problems and what we try to do is anticipate
what the problems are, and already have research teams in place or the beginnings of that put together so that we can respond.
Our best bet is if we can anticipate the problem before they do, before they begin to feel, so that we can respond by saying, yes, we're working in that area, here's what we can do for you.
So what we do, we work in the future.
We work on things that haven't been done before.
That's Mars.
Figure out what it is next.
So you've done that with education in terms of the start.
Are there any other things that you know of since you've been here?
Oh, sure.
Space, the space technology effort and space exploitation and commercialization.
Doreen can tell you much more about that.
But what we did, we do program reviews once a year.
We sit down with every division head.
and talk about what they have done, what they want to do, what their major problems are, where they see research going.
And a recurring theme here before last was that there's going to be a renewed emphasis in space.
But with a different, not just in getting there and getting back, but what do you do once you're there.
And so we began to join that area and began to put together some effort and some research activities there, some planning.
And it's been since then that the president has come out and said, we're going to have a station.
And that...
There has been private companies spring up that are trying to launch their own rockets and go into business because they think there's going to be a profit.
That NASA's thinking about turning the shuttle over to some private contractor for a commercial operation.
So that they anticipate it.
All we have to do a lot of times is listen.
You just have to keep your ear to the ground to figure out what it is that's going to be on the floor.
Who do you listen to?
Researchers and... Well, yes and no.
People.
You can read, you know, you can follow a chain of events and just kind of begin to see.
If you think far enough...

you think that in itself is a skill to oh yeah yeah i read something recently that described it really well and this psychologist or sociologist said that there are one-year people and there are 10-year people and five-year people he said some people if you're a one-year person you can only think in one-year time frame and you think everybody else thinks that way too mom i i have always
well, for a long time.

I don't guess I was aware of it, but for a long time I've known that I think of ideas and can go ahead and get them in place, but they may not be really implemented and used for three, four, five, ten years.
Come up with products for others.
Yeah, it just happens that, you know, the
The use and application and receptivity to some of that stuff just takes longer for other people to become comfortable with.
But you've got to have all of those kinds of people.
You can't have all people that just think in tenured terms.
I mean, think way out there.
Or you wouldn't get today's problem solved.
But in terms of planning programs.
Yeah.
This is a biggie.
This is my life.
What is your general assessment of the value of TEAS to A&M, to the state, to the nation, to the world?
You want to start there and then I'll ask the rest of them?
TEAS is a benefit to Texas A&M University that Texas A&M University does not really realize, I think.
and that it is a place that has the flexibility to respond to long-term ideas and to short-range needs.
If a researcher comes in today and says,
boy, if I could just do this, this, and this, then we'd have this research project, and this would really help where we're going.
It would help Texas A&M.
We don't see ourselves as separate and apart.
The people who work for us are both.
I think that's hard for administrators that are in charge of academics to realize sometimes, is we're not trying to fight over.
who this person belongs to.
We're just trying to support good programs.
In fact, a lot of the programs that TEAS has developed traditionally have then become university properties, so to speak.
The cyclotron, the data processing center.
There are things like that that initially were started by TEAS, either because TEAS had
fiscal capability and flexibility, because it has a flexibility with its financial status that the university has not felt it had, I think, sometimes.
And also, T seems to me to be the place that's been able to take a calculated risk.
and say, yeah, let's try this.
We'll try cyclotron and then if it's not what we need, well, you know, there have been a lot of things that they've shut down.
But it's a place where you can, that's what research is all about.
I think it's given the state very recently a capability and a
They didn't have to waste energy, time, and resources going to create something like this.
They can draw upon something they've been in place for 70 years.
I think it will become more important to the state in the next 20 years than it has in the past simply because if you will look at the scale
You can almost see an upturn.
We have, in the last four years, grown at over 25% per year.
Fiscally?
Fiscally.
There is a larger demand for what we do, and there is going to be a larger need for what we do in the future, especially in Texas.
We're going to become a high technology state.
There needs to be a resource for those industries to draw on, for...
capable answers to questions, working relationships, and also at trained talent.
What is the value of T's to basic science research versus technology research?
I'm not sure that there is a difference.
I'd be interested in your definition of what
I'm not sure there's a difference.
Dr. Seeley is sure there's a definite difference, and he hasn't been able to explain it to me well enough for me to understand it either.
But to the extent that...
basic science is the theory upon which you build the reality of technology.
Sure, but you've got to start it with a problem.
Right.
Okay, and to me that's if you have a problem then you're working on something that's applied before you can get into the basics.
I think there's research and there's development.
Okay.
And I think that in the body of research it's very hard to tell what's basic and applied.
or generic, because you may be working on a particular application to discover something that's very generic in its nature that applies to you.
Not intentionally, but you can prevent that from happening.
Also, you can be working on something very basic, but the purpose of basic research is to discover things that are of benefit, which means they have application.
you can't structure it where you do one or the other.
What you can say is this is the research part and this is the development.
This is where I take it to the marketplace.
So is TEAS involved in both?
TEAS was not involved in the marketing or the commercialization as much in the past as it might be in the future through Inven.
Inven is a vehicle where
when you discover something you can do that.
Or we also are much more sophisticated in our trying to be aware of how that will benefit the researcher and the university and the state.
An example is there's a researcher in food protein who recently discovered a patentable process for
I don't know what it is, but something that works with privacy.
There is a university system patent office.
The patent was secured.
Dan Davis negotiated a contract licensing agreement with a company from Japan.
And Jim Mahon's taking home
a minimum of $200,000 a year for the next two years, and probably the estimates on a max would be $2 million a year.
That same amount of money comes back to the university system or to TEAS as a system part, since that's where it gets work.
But that's development, and we help with that.
But the research is really important.
I'd be interested in Dr. Seymour's definition.
Some people have said basic research is what you do when you don't know what you're doing.
Well, the pure science, I think, versus the engineering, I think, is the difference.
In that standpoint, I'd be from Missouri.
I'd say, show me what the difference is.
Because I can take him into some laboratories and...
The Zachry building, there are far more pure science than most of the things you'll find in the chemistry department.
They're physics.
They're solid state electronics, but that's physics.
And it's back to the interdisciplinary question.
And I don't know that you can pull it apart that much.
It'll be interesting to see.
Is there anything else you'd like to add to this that you think I should know that I don't know or that I haven't asked?
You will run across the demo as you go along.
Let me know if there's questions.
I'd like to feel free to call you up again.
I don't know all the answers, but I can point you to the right questions.
Thank you very much.
